content.description: Awesome route! Start on easy slab and head up to the blank, blunt, left facing arete under the roof. Decipher the cryptic moves on the arete and then traverse the lip of the roof from left to right. Sick.
Start just left of Wind Traveler. Climb cruxy crack to the cruiser roof.
Climbing is good, there are tricky moves low to pumpy moves high. The rock is crumbly at the last two bolts. Tends to stay on the damp side, especially high.
content.location: The route is directly left of the waterfall at Gauley Crag. The position alone of this route warrants giving it a try. Leave the locking cleaning biner midway.

content.description: Begin around the corner left of wind traveler. Climb through pockety crux and pull small roof to top out.

Start on the small arete at the low roof. Get established on the slab, then work up the left facing, left leaning, dihedral to a steeper blocky section. Pull through to a right leaning hand-sized crack behind a large flake, following the crack to a ledge below the roof. Hand jam out the roof to the finger-sized crack on the face above, using some power and balance to get a stance to clip the anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack to a BD 2 or 3. Doubles in the BD .4-.75 range. Bolted anchor.
content.location: The farthest route to the left, just around the corner from the two short lichen covered 5.6s (Gumby Crack and Gumby Flakes).

content.description: The route's namesake is the hold to the right of the first bolt, and from the ground it looks like it's glued on (it's not!). Great route that needs more traffic.
content.location: Short hike climber's left from the main area. Look for the hold at the lip beneath a low roof with a bolt next to it. This will be the first bolted route you will come to after leaving the Gauliseum.

content.description:
Beautiful flake/right facing corner that just looks like it wants to be climbed.  The route is a bit licheny as is, but with some more traffic this would be a real gem for the crag.  The roof moves offer excellent movement, and can be exciting, because you may not want to stop to place pro!

I was pretty gripped by the topout, and was sad to have used my 0.75-#1 C4s down low.  Consider saving a piece that size to protect the stout topout.

60' to 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 0.5-3 C4s and a few big stoppers.  Triple #1s would make sewing it up easy.
content.location: Climber's left of the waterfall a several hundred feet.  If you follow the cliff you won't miss it.

content.description:
Stickclip the first bolt and boulder your ass off for ~20 feet until you hit a jug. Continue through the dihedral on great sidepulls and a long reach.

Crawling with spiders in the summer. Clipping the first bolt without a stickclip felt impossible unless you were 6'4"+
content.location: Left of the Gauliseum, on the arete. Starts in a seam to the right of the first bolt.

content.description:
"The scraps of Megos," named after Alex came through and made short work of many of the NRG region's hardest lines. In the 2nd ed. guidebook, this is listed as a project that is "possibly 12d."

Climb up a sandy slab to the base of a roof (this route did not get the memo that roofs should have jug rails at the back of them).  Git buck out the roof, fire a crux just past that to a good horizontal.  One more roof takes you to an ultra-techy face and finger crack, and then the anchors.
content.location: Far left end of the Gauliseum, just before the cliffline turns a corner.
